edu.brown.cs.systems.tracingplane.transit_layer

Interface Baggage

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    BaggageAtoms, BaggageContents
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericBaggageContents, NullBaggage, RawBaggageAtoms

    public interface Baggage

    Baggage is a general purpose request context. The purpose of Baggage is to provide a way to propagate arbitrary request context alongside a request as the request traverses different thread, process, machine, and application boundaries. This interface -- Baggage -- is the base unit of context in the tracing plane. Everything that is propagated by the tracing plane ultimately inherits from this interface. Thus, when using Baggage in application code, most variables will be of type Baggage, and most method calls will be to static methods in this interface.

    This interface is the TransitLayer interface for Baggage. This interface has the core TransitLayer static methods to enable you to create new Baggage instances; serialize and deserialize Baggage instances; create copies to pass to new threads or attach to continuations; and merge multiple contexts from joining branches (eg, when multiple threads join, when parent continuations complete and trigger a child continuation; when a message is received from the network).

    The sole purpose of this layer is to make sure that request context follows the path of request execution. When a new thread is created to process a request, Baggage should be copied to the new thread. When a network request is made, serialized Baggage should be included with the request. When a worker thread completes execution for a request and moves on to the next one, it should drop the previous request's Baggage. In general, when using this layer, you should be thinking more about "what is the logical extent of this request?" and less about "I want to include X, Y, Z IDs with my request". Other layers -- e.g., AtomLayer and BaggageLayer -- provide implementations and interfaces for the contents of Baggage.

    Manipulation of Baggage should be done via the static methods in this class -- eg, newInstance , discard, branch, join, serialize, deserialize. The methods of this class can be divided into two groups. The first group of methods require you to explicitly provide Baggage instances as method arguments. The second group of methods does not require explicit Baggage instances as arguments, instead accessing a thread-local variable whose contents contain the current thread's Baggage.

    • Field Detail

      • transit

        static final TransitLayer<?> transit
        The TransitLayer implementation installed in the process.

    • Method Detail

      • newInstance

        static Baggage newInstance()

        This method does not affect the Baggage set for the current thread.

        This method creates and returns a new, empty baggage. Be aware that most TransitLayer implementations represent empty Baggage using null, so the return value of this method is quite likely to be null.

        If you wish set the current thread's baggage to a new instance (and discard anything that was previously set), either of the following approaches can be used instead:

        • Call discard(), which will discard anything previously set, effectively setting the thread's current baggage to a new empty instance, e.g.,
          Baggage.discard();
        • Pass the return value of newInstance() to set(Baggage), which will overwrite the thread's current baggage with the newly created instance, e.g.,
          Baggage.set(Baggage.newInstance());
        Returns:
        An empty Baggage instance. The return value can be null, as null corresponds to the empty baggage.

      • get

        static Baggage get()

        Gets the Baggage instance, if any, being stored for the current thread.

        Be aware that this method does not branch the baggage instance, so in general this method should only be used to, for example, inspect the contents of the baggage. You can, however, call branch(Baggage) manually if you wish to continue to use the Baggage.

        Returns:
        a Baggage instance, possibly null

      • take

        static Baggage take()

        Removes the baggage instance being stored by the current thread, and returns it.

        No calls to branch(Baggage) are necessary on the returned baggage after calling this method, because the current thread will no longer have access to it.

        Returns:
        a Baggage instance, possibly null.

      • set

        static void set(Baggage baggage)

        Set the baggage being stored by the current thread.

        This method does not branch the baggage instance provided, so if you wish to continue to use baggage after calling this method, you should branch it.

        Parameters:
        baggage - a Baggage instance, possibly null

      • discard

        static void discard()

        Discards the Baggage set in the current thread. Subsequent interactions with the current thread's baggage will encounter a new empty instance.

        If your system has worker threads that process requests in a loop, you should typically call discard() at the end of each loop, to ensure that the Baggage belonging to the previous request does not 'leak' to future requests or to maintenance work that is unrelated to the request.

        A call to this method is equivalent to Baggage.discard(Baggage.take());

        If you wish to discard a specific Baggage instance and not the one set in the current thread, use discard(Baggage).

      • discard

        static void discard(Baggage baggage)

        Discards the provided baggage instance, rendering it no longer usable.

        This method does not affect Baggage set for the current thread. To discard the current thread's Baggage, use discard().

        It is recommended, but not necessary, to call this method if you know that you will not be using this Baggage instance again in future. This has a minor effect of preventing unnecessary Baggage contents copying if the instance was branched and the branched copy is still in use.

        Parameters:
        baggage - The Baggage instance to discard. After calling this method you should not use the baggage instance again.

      • branch

        static Baggage branch()

        Create a copy of the Baggage set in the current thread.

        If a request is being processed concurrently -- for example, by multiple threads, or with multiple work items in a thread pool -- then the concurrent branches should not share one Baggage instance. Instead, concurrent branches should each have their own Baggage instance. This is done by calling branch() prior to spinning off the concurrent execution (e.g., before creating the thread or work item) and giving the thread or work item the copied Baggage. Examples of when branch() should be called include:

        • When we create a new thread, branch the current thread's Baggage so that the new thread has its own copy to work with: 
           Baggage branchedBaggage = Baggage.branch();
 Thread t = new Thread() {
     public void run() {
         Baggage.set(branchedBaggage); 
         ...
         Baggage.discard();
     }
 }
 t.start();
        • When creating Runnable instances or similar work objects that will be passed to a Executor or other thread pool, branch the current thread's Baggage so that each work object has its own copy to work with: 
           Baggage branchedBaggage = Baggage.branch();
 Runnable r = new Runnable() {
     public void run() {
         Baggage.set(branchedBaggage); 
         ...
         Baggage.discard();
     }
 }
 myExecutor.submit(r);
        • Making a remote network request, branch the current thread's Baggage then serialize the copy for inclusion in the network request: 
           byte[] baggageBytes = Baggage.serialize(Baggage.branch());
 ... // make network request, include baggageBytes in header

        If the concurrent executions later join (e.g., by calling Thread.join() or awaiting a Future), their respective Baggage instances should be merged with join(Baggage).

        If you wish to branch a specific Baggage instance and not the one set in the current thread, use branch(Baggage).

        Returns:
        a copy of the baggage that is set for the current thread. Note that the return value can be null (if the thread's baggage is empty).

      • branch

        static Baggage branch(Baggage from)

        Create a copy of the provided Baggage instance.

        This method does not affect Baggage set for the current thread. To create a copy of the current thread's Baggage, use branch().

        If a request is being processed concurrently -- for example, by multiple threads, or with multiple work items in a thread pool -- then the concurrent branches should not share one Baggage instance. Instead, concurrent branches should each have their own Baggage instance. This is done by calling branch() prior to spinning off the concurrent execution (e.g., before creating the thread or work item) and giving the thread or work item the copied Baggage. Examples of when branch() should be called include:

        • When we create a new thread, branch the current thread's Baggage so that the new thread has its own copy to work with: 
           Baggage b;
 Thread t = new Thread() {
     public void run() {
         Baggage.set(Baggage.branch(b)); 
         ...
         Baggage.discard();
     }
 }
        • When creating Runnable instances or similar work objects that will be passed to a Executor or other thread pool, branch the current thread's Baggage so that each work object has its own copy to work with: 
           Baggage b;
 Runnable r = new Runnable() {
     public void run() {
         Baggage.set(Baggage.branch(b)); 
         ...
         Baggage.discard();
     }
 }
        • Making a remote network request, branch the current thread's Baggage then serialize the copy for inclusion in the network request: 
           Baggage b;
 byte[] baggageBytes = Baggage.serialize(Baggage.branch(b));
 ... // make network request, include baggageBytes in header

        If the concurrent executions later join (e.g., by calling Thread.join() or awaiting a Future), their respective Baggage instances should be merged with join(Baggage, Baggage).

        Parameters:
        from - a baggage instance to create a copy of, allowed to be null.
        Returns:
        a copy of the baggage instance provided. Note that the return value can be null (if baggage is empty). This method also might return the same instance provided as argument -- however, the call to branch is still necessary to update internal reference counters.

      • join

        static void join(Baggage other)

        Merges the baggage that is set in the current thread with the baggage instance provided. After this call, the baggage set in the current thread will contain both its original contents and the contents of other.

        join should be used if your application uses multiple threads or runnables to process each request. When the concurrent branches of execution complete, use join to merge back together their contents. Examples of when join(Baggage) should be called include:

        • After a concurrent thread finishes, merge its Baggage after we call Thread.join(): 
           class MyThread extends Thread {
     Baggage baggage;
     public void run() {
         ...
         this.baggage = Baggage.take();
     }
 }
 
 MyThread thread;
 thread.start();
 ...
 thread.join();
 Baggage.join(thread.baggage);
        • After a runnable or similar work object completes execution, merge its Baggage: 
            
 class MyRunnable extends Runnable {
     Baggage baggage;
     public void run() {
         ... 
         this.baggage = Baggage.take();
     }
 }
 
 ExecutorService executor;
 MyRunnable runnable;
 Future<?> future = executor.submit(runnable);
 ...
 future.get();
 Baggage.join(runnable.baggage);
        • After receiving a remove network request or response to a request, merge the Baggage included in the response with the Baggage of the receiving thread: 
           byte[] networkBaggageBytes;
 Baggage.join(Baggage.deserialize(networkBaggageBytes));

        After calling join, other should not be used any further. If you wish to continue to use other then you should branch other first, e.g., Baggage.join(Baggage.branch(other));.

        If you wish to join two Baggage instances and not the one set in the current thread, use join(Baggage, Baggage).

        Parameters:
        other - another Baggage instance, whose contents you wish to merge into the current thread's baggage. other may be null. After this call, other should not be used.

      • join

        static Baggage join(Baggage left,
                    Baggage right)

        Merges the contents of two baggage instances into a single instance. The baggage returned by this call will contain the contents of both left and right.

        This method does not affect Baggage set for the current thread. To merge a baggage instance with the current thread's Baggage, use join(Baggage) instead.

        join should be used if your application uses multiple threads or runnables to process each request. When the concurrent branches of execution complete, use join to merge back together their contents. Examples of when join(Baggage, Baggage) should be called include:

        • After a concurrent thread finishes, merge its Baggage after we call Thread.join(): 
           class MyThread extends Thread {
     Baggage baggage;
     public void run() {
         ...
         this.baggage = Baggage.take();
     }
 }
 
 MyThread threadA, threadB;
 threadA.start();
 threadB.start();
 ...
 threadA.join();
 threadB.join();
 Baggage merged = Baggage.join(threadA.baggage, threadB.baggage);
        • After a runnable or similar work object completes execution, merge its Baggage: 
            
 Baggage completedBaggage;
 
 class MyRunnable extends Runnable {
     public void run() {
         ... 
         completedBaggage = Baggage.join(completedBaggage, Baggage.get());
     }
 }
 
 ExecutorService executor;
 MyRunnable runnableA, runnableB, runnableC;
 Future<?> future = executor.submit(runnableA);
 Future<?> future = executor.submit(runnableB);
 Future<?> future = executor.submit(runnableC);
 ...
 futureA.get();
 futureB.get();
 futureC.get();
 Baggage.set(completedBaggage);

        After calling join, left and right should not be used any further. If you wish to continue to use them then you should branch them first, e.g., Baggage.join(Baggage.branch(left), Baggage.branch(right));.

        Parameters:
        left - a baggage instance, which may be null. After this call, left should not be used again.
        right - a baggage instance, which may be null. After this call, right should not be used again.
        Returns:
        a baggage instance a baggage instances whose contents contain the contents of left merged with the contents of right

      • deserialize

        static Baggage deserialize(byte[] serialized)

        Deserialize a serialized Baggage instance.

        This method does not affect the baggage set for the current thread. If you wish to set or join the deserialized baggage, you must call the corresponding methods, e.g.,
        Baggage.set(Baggage.deserialize(serialized));
        Baggage.join(Baggage.deserialize(serialized));

        If the provided bytes cannot be deserialized (e.g., because they are invalid), then they will be treated as the empty baggage and the return value of this method will be null. However, a return value of null does not imply that the bytes are invalid.

        Parameters:
        serialized - the serialized byte representation of Baggage.
        Returns:
        the deserialized Baggage instance, possibly null

      • deserialize

        static Baggage deserialize(byte[] serialized,
                           int offset,
                           int length)

        Deserialize a serialized Baggage instance.

        This method does not affect the baggage set for the current thread. If you wish to set or join the deserialized baggage, you must call the corresponding methods, e.g.,
        Baggage.set(Baggage.deserialize(serialized, offset, length));
        Baggage.join(Baggage.deserialize(serialized, offset, length));

        If the provided bytes cannot be deserialized (e.g., because they are invalid), then they will be treated as the empty baggage and the return value of this method will be null. However, a return value of null does not imply that the bytes are invalid.

        Parameters:
        serialized - the serialized byte representation of Baggage.
        offset - offset into the byte array where the Baggage begins
        length - length of the baggage bytes
        Returns:
        the deserialized Baggage instance, possibly null

      • readFrom

        static Baggage readFrom(java.io.InputStream in)
                 throws java.io.IOException

        Deserialize a serialized Baggage instance by reading it from the provided InputStream. It is expected that the TransitLayer implementation will precede the baggage bytes with a length prefix.

        This method does not affect the baggage set for the current thread. If you wish to set or join the deserialized baggage, you must call the corresponding methods, e.g.,
        Baggage.set(Baggage.readFrom(in));
        Baggage.join(Baggage.readFrom(in));

        If the provided bytes cannot be deserialized (e.g., because they are invalid), then they will be treated as the empty baggage and the return value of this method will be null. However, a return value of null does not imply that the bytes are invalid.

        Parameters:
        in - the stream to read from
        Returns:
        the deserialized Baggage instance, possibly null
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an exception occurs reading from in

      • serialize

        static byte[] serialize()

        Serialize the baggage that is set for the current thread.

        Returns:
        the serialized representation of the current thread's Baggage. The returned bytes might be null or the empty byte array, both of which are valid and can be used to indicate the empty Baggage.

      • serialize

        static byte[] serialize(Baggage baggage)

        Serialize a baggage instance to its byte representation.

        After calling serialize, baggage can continue to be used. serialize implicitly branches the baggage before serializing.

        Parameters:
        baggage - a baggage instance to serialize, possibly null
        Returns:
        the serialized byte representation of the baggage

      • writeTo

        static void writeTo(java.io.OutputStream out,
                    Baggage baggage)
             throws java.io.IOException

        Write a baggage instance to an OutputStream. The TransitLayer will write the length of the serialized representation then write the bytes.

        After calling writeTo, baggage can continue to be used. serialize implicitly branches the baggage before serializing.

        Parameters:
        out - an outputstream to write the baggage to
        baggage - a baggage instance to write, possibly null. If null, this method will write a zero-length byte array.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - propagated from out
